content.raw:
It looks like there is some very strange/hard transition for

```
virtual_stix.ign  robotName1:=X2 robotConfig1:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3
```

resulting in many false collisions:

```
0:00:03.057975 go_straight 7.0 (speed: 0.5) (0.0, 0.0, -0.7923794804054256)
0:00:03.151615 Collision! [18.273, 0.004, 18.782] reported: False
0:00:03.176237 Collision! [25.47, 0.0, 19.8] reported: False
0:00:38.168127 Collision! [-19.87, -0.011, 21.035] reported: True
```

i.e. X2 was not able to enter the tunnel \(for virtual STIX\).

content.raw:
I am reopening this as bug because … the accelerometer value depends on the controller speed. I reduced logging of communication to ROS and large images in order to be sure that within 1hour the OSGAR log file is not too big and the local simulation docker now triggers collisions at the tunnel entrance as X2 tries to stop. :disappointed: 

Was there any change related to machine speed and accelerometer simulation?! \(somehow it reminds me issues with IMU?? In release notes I see 13th Sept “Updated the collision of the ramp tunnel.” is it related??

`osrf/subt-virtual-testbed                                    cloudsim_bridge_latest        d8c6a32fef70        2 weeks ago         3.41GB`

Or are there ramp-up/ramp-down necessary for speed control of X2 robot?

Hi Martin,

Can you try the following locally?  Instead of sending a forward velocity of 0.5, can you start with 0.1 and slowly ramp up to 0.5?
content.html:
Hi Martin,

Can you try the following locally? Instead of sending a forward velocity of 0.5, can you start with 0.1 and slowly ramp up to 0.5?

content.raw: Are these values directly from the accelerometer or are you calculating them? Some of the major outliers you’re pointing out could be impulse responses to collisions \(i.e. instanteous 7G from changing ground planes without suspension is certainly possible with the right speed\). Is this related to an issue you’re having?
content.html: Are these values directly from the accelerometer or are you calculating them? Some of the major outliers you’re pointing out could be impulse responses to collisions (i.e. instanteous 7G from changing ground planes without suspension is certainly possible with the right speed). Is this related to an issue you’re having?

content.raw: these are raw values, 1:1 converted from ROS … 7G could be the collision, but the “jitter” is suspicious.
content.html: these are raw values, 1:1 converted from ROS … 7G could be the collision, but the “jitter” is suspicious.

content.raw:
@{5cf75629ff02b50ea27b2817} I would re-world the actual question:

Suppose you have X2 \(or better real Clearpath Jackal\) with IMU mounted and that you control it via ROS. It is stand still and you send command go 1m/s and after few seconds you send command 0m/s … what reading would you expect on IMU/accelerometer?

‌
content.html:
@Alfredo Bencomo I would re-world the actual question:

Suppose you have X2 (or better real Clearpath Jackal) with IMU mounted and that you control it via ROS. It is stand still and you send command go 1m/s and after few seconds you send command 0m/s … what reading would you expect on IMU/accelerometer?

‌

content.raw: There is no acceleration limit on the X1 or the X2 so commanding `1m/s` would generate ~1g for one time step of the simulation.
content.html: There is no acceleration limit on the X1 or the X2 so commanding 1m/s would generate ~1g for one time step of the simulation.

content.raw: To clarify, the 1g acceleration is limited by the surface friction.
content.html: To clarify, the 1g acceleration is limited by the surface friction.
